citeinfo.title: Changes in Anthropogenic Influences on Streams and Rivers: Pesticide Use

descript.abstract: This dataset contains data for estimated agricultural use of pesticides for five year periods from 1992-2012, for Hydrologic Unit Code 10 (HUC-10) areas. Values are given for "high" and "low" estimates for each five year period for 17 pesticides: 2,4-D, Acetochlor, Alachlor, Atrazine, Carbaryl, Chlorpyrifos, Clothianidin, Diazinon, Dicamba, Fipronil, Glyphosate, Imidacloprid, Malathion, Metolachlor, Simazine, Tebuthiuron, and Thiamethoxam. Data are given in units of kilograms (kg) per square kilometer (sq km). Data are derived from U.S. Geological Survey pesticide use data mapped to agricultural lands.
descript.purpose: These data are intended to provide a framework in which watershed-specific studies of water quality in streams and rivers may be analyzed. The focus of the data is on anthropogenic changes over time.
descript.supplinf: Seventeen comma-separated text files are given here: one for each of the pesticides noted in the abstract. Each text file here contains a "uniqid" field, which is the link to the data in all other datasets in this product. Each file has 15,458 rows. Source county data were provided by Nancy Baker of the U.S. Geological Survey in January 2018, derived from USGS data located at https://water.usgs.gov/nawqa/pnsp/usage/maps/ (U.S. Geological Survey, 2017). These were provided in the tabular format by county, in units of kg of pesticide for a "high" and "low" estimate, for the years 1992, 1997, 2002, 2007, and 2012. Most pesticides are present in every year, but a few are not, see below. Each table has a "high" and "low" estimate for the available years (Thelin and Stone, 2013). The distinction between "high" and "low" is described in Thelin and Stone, 2013, but in summary, if a compound/crop was surveyed but no use was reported then the "low" estimate is given as 0 in the source data, but the "high" estimate is taken from neighboring areas (crop reporting districts or farm resource regions). To improve the mapping of the source county data, they were allocated to agricultural land use pixels from the NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Land-use Trends (NWALT; Falcone, 2016) product to create national 1-kilometer rasters. The steps for doing this are described below under Process Steps. Metolachlor is a combination of Metolachlor and Metolachlor-S from the source data. The years available for each compound, and the abbreviation used in the data tables, are: 2,4-D (1992-2012) (24d) Acetochlor (1997-2012) (aceto) Alachlor (1992-2012) (alach) Atrazine (1992-2012) (atraz) Carbaryl (1992-2012) (carba) Chlorpyrifos (1992-2012) (chlor) Clothianidin (2007-2012) (cloth) Diazinon (1992-2012) (diazi) Dicamba (1992-2012) (dicam) Fipronil (2002-2012) (fipro) Glyphosate (1992-2012) (glyph) Imidacloprid (1997-2012) (imada) Malathion (1992-2012) (malat) Metolachlor (1992-2012) (melo) (combination of Metolachlor and Metolachlor-S) Simazine (1992-2012) (simaz) Tebuthiuron (1992-2012) (tebut) Thiamethoxam (2002-2012) (thiam) HUC-10 boundaries were obtained on January 9, 2018 from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) at https://nrcs.app.box.com/v/huc/folder/39640323180 (National Resources Conservation Service, 2017). References: Falcone, J.A., 2016, Mapping enhanced grazing potential based on the NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Land-use Trends (NWALT) product, 1974-2012: U.S. Geological Survey data release, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F7CR5RFF. National Historical Geographic Information System (NHGIS), 2013, U.S. Geographic Summary Data and Boundary Files, 2000 county boundaries, accessed February 1, 2013 at: https://www.nhgis.org/. National Resources Conservation Service, 2017, Watershed boundary dataset (WBD): National Resources Conservation Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, available at https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/main/national/technical/nra/geo/, accessed January 9, 2018 from https://nrcs.app.box.com/v/huc/folder/39640323180. Thelin, G.P., and Stone, W.W., 2013, Estimation of annual agricultural pesticide use for counties of the conterminous United States, 1992â€“2009: U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report 2013-5009, 54 p, available at https://pubs.usgs.gov/sir/2013/5009/. U.S. Geological Survey, 2017, Estimated annual agricultural pesticide use: U.S. Geological Survey Pesticide National Synthesis Project web page, accessed January 18, 2018, at https://dx.doi.org/doi:10.5066/F7NP22KM.

attracc.attraccr: These data were derived from 1-kilometer (km) resolution grids which were created by allocating the source county data to "agricultural" land use pixels from the NAWQA Wall-to-Wall Anthropogenic Landuse Trends (NWALT) dataset. The creation of these grids is described below under Process Steps. The fidelity of the grids to the original county data was measured by summing the grids' values by county, then comparing that to the original tabular data. This was done for one random year for each of the 17 pesticides. Of these 17 tests, at least 99% of counties agreed with the original county data within +/- 5%. What differences there are, are primarily a function of the 1-km spatial resolution of the grids, that is, because some pixels cross county borders.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

srcinfo.srccontr: HUC-10 boundaries used in data calculations.

citeinfo.title: Estimated annual agricultural pesticide use: U.S. Geological Survey Pesticide National Synthesis Project web page

srcinfo.srccontr: County-level pesticide data used to created rasters
County boundaries used to join tabular county data to and in data calculations.

citeinfo.title: Mapping enhanced grazing potential based on the NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Land-use Trends (NWALT) product, 1974-2012

srcinfo.srccontr: 60-meter national land use rasters to which tabular statistics were allocated

procstep.procdesc: (1) Source county data from U.S. Geological Survey, 2017 were joined to NHGIS, 2013 (U.S. county boundary for the year 2000). A 1-km raster was created from this, which had the pesticide usage values joined by county.

(2) Previously-created 1-km rasters were used to map kg of pesticides to land use pixels, from the NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Landuse Trends (NWALT) product (Falcone, 2016). These rasters represented each pixel's proportion of classes 43 (Crops) plus 44 (Pasture/Hay) in the county for the years 1992, 2002, and 2012. That is, if a county had 1000 acres of classes 43 and 44, and 10 1-km pixels in the county each had an identical amount of that, they would all have values 0.1.

(3) The kg of pesticide from (1) were multiplied by the grids in (2), to allocate the county kg of pesticide use to land use pixels. For 1992 and 1997 the 1992 NWALT was used, for 2002 and 2007 the 2002 NWALT was used, and for 2012 the 2012 NWALT was used.

(4) A small number of counties had pesticide usage but no class 43 nor 44 pixels in the NWALT grid. For these counties the following mapping was used: - San Juan, CO (FIPS 08111), Loving, TX (FIPS 48301), and Terrel, TX (FIPS 48443): NWALT classes 45 + 46 were used ("Grazing potential" classes). - San Francisco, CA (FIPS 06075): all NWALT anthropogenic classes used (because no 45 or 46 present).

(5) The above steps resulted in 152 national 1-km rasters, one for each pesticide-year-type (high vs low) combination. Each raster has values of kg of pesticides per sq km, allocated to agricultural land use pixels (with exception of the counties noted in (4)).
(6) HUC-10 watershed averages were calculated for each pesticide and year using the zonalmean() command in ArcGIS Grid.

detailed.Name: pest_24d-huc10.txt, pest_aceto-huc10.txt, pest_alach-huc10.txt, pest_atraz-huc10.txt, pest_carba-huc10.txt, pest_chlor-huc10.txt, pest_cloth-huc10.txt, pest_diazi-huc10.txt, pest_dicam-huc10.txt, pest_fipro-huc10.txt, pest_glyph-huc10.txt, pest_imida-huc10.txt, pest_malat-huc10.txt, pest_meto-huc10.txt, pest_simaz-huc10.txt, pest_tebut-huc10.txt, pest_thiam-huc10.txt

enttyp.enttypd: Data consist of comma-separated text files. There are 17 tables: pest_24d-huc10.txt, pest_aceto-huc10.txt, pest_alach-huc10.txt, pest_atraz-huc10.txt, pest_carba-huc10.txt, pest_chlor-huc10.txt, pest_cloth-huc10.txt, pest_diazi-huc10.txt, pest_dicam-huc10.txt, pest_fipro-huc10.txt, pest_glyph-huc10.txt, pest_imida-huc10.txt, pest_malat-huc10.txt, pest_meto-huc10.txt, pest_simaz-huc10.txt, pest_tebut-huc10.txt, and pest_thiam-huc10.txt
